beers.description:
# Beer Description

A Beer Cloaked in Secrecy, An ale whose mysterious and unusual palate will swirl across your tongue and ask more questions than it answers. A beer brewed clandestinely and given a name whose meaning is never revealed. Why #9? Why, indeed. A sort of dry, crisp, fruity, refreshing, not-quite pale ale. #9 is really impossible to describe because there's never been anything else quite like it. Fermented with our 150 year old strain of top-fermenting English yeast.

# What You Should Know

\#9 starts with the base of a traditional Pale Ale- pale and crystal malts that are light and somewhat sweet. Cascade and Centennial hops, two varieties that are used very commonly in craft beer, so it's a familiar base. The secret differentiator is the addition of apricot flavorings (it's top secret what gives the actual flavor) to give the beer a sweet and fruity finish.

# The Boy's Take

This one is interesting- a sorta hybrid with a solid pale ale start and little bit of an interesting fruit twist at the end. It's eminently drinkable and a really solid choice.

# About the Brewer

Magic Hat was founded in 1994 in Burlington, VT and quickly proved to be a successful pioneer in the craft beer space. The interesting thing about Magic Hat is that they provide beer that is palatable to a mainstream audience or new craft beer drinkers, but at the same time are known for quirkiness and creativity in their marketing in culture. A trip to the artifactory is a bit of a crazy ride, with haunted-house décor, real pieces of art and free beer samplers. In 2008, it was time to grow and Magic Hat acquired Pyramid brewing from Washington state, giving them a coast to coast reach. Finally, North American Breweries (owned by a private equity group that also owns Genesee and Dundee brewing), came in to add Magic Hat to its empire in 2010- which means more Magic Hat beer everywhere!

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, Brown Ales, Fruit Beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Apricots, secret formulas, Wikileaks

# Drink While You Are

Touring Mr. Magoo's Magic Emporium, performing a magic trick

# Pair With

Indian, Thai, Chinese, Southwestern

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Like the digits suggest, it's a beer that's densely populated with flavor and loaded with character. We don't filter it, so none of its life and soul is stripped away. The first thing you notice is the hazy, cloudy appearance. That's how you know it's unfiltered. What hits you next is the spicy aroma of Cascade hops, followed by the crispy, fruity ale flavor delivered in a smooth, creamy body, the result of blending barley malt with torrified wheat. It's not like any other Goose Island Beer, but no less that you'd expect.

# What you should know

"Torrified" wheat has been heated slightly until it "pops"- then making it more receptive to mixing with the other malts in this brew. Like other Wheat ales, the actual wheat is included as part of the recipe.

# The Boy's Take

The crafty cure to the common wheat beer. This solid wheat beer brewed by the folks at Goose Island once again proves that just because they got picked up by the big guys doesn't mean they're not still making great craft beer!

# About the Brewer

Goose Island is Chicago's microbrewery, launched in 1988 by founder John Hall, just returned from a European tour. More than just making good craft beer, Hall advocated for it, helping bring consciousness of this new revolution to one of the US's largest cities. This meant growth, and by 1995, it was time for another brewery. Along the way, Hall had built smaller pilot beer labs and 143,000 sqft of barrel space for barrel-aging beers. This was revolutionary, and it got Goose Island its name, especially for the Bourbon Country Barrel-Aged Stout (released once a year on Black Friday and notorious for creating long lines far from the shopping malls). But eventually there was a cap to the growth, and Annheiser-Busch came calling. Yes, Goose Island has been owned by A-B for several years and that has meant… a lot more Goose Island. Most would agree, the quality of the beer is still top-notch, you just can get Goose Island in a lot more places, thanks to A-B. And there's nothing wrong with that.

# Drink this if You Like

Wheats, Hefes, Wits

# Ideal for People who Like

Geese, The Windy City, Being Unfiltered

# Drink While You Are

At home in your library, looking out over Lake Michigan, catching a Cubs game

# Pair With

Burgers, Fried Chicken, Chicago Style Pizza

# Beer Description: 

Crafted in the city that gives us 329 days of sun, 329 Lager is the perfect companion for making the most of sunny California days. Our go anywhere, do anything lager is full-flavored and easy-drinking with a clean, crisp finish.

# The Boys’ Take: 

A great smooth American lager that is a great way to step into craft beer and away from some of those so called “American Lagers”…  

# About the Brewer:  

Golden Road Brewing was founded in 2011 by Meg Gill and Tony Yanow in Los Angeles, California. They focus on brewing beer that is sustainable and their community together. Golden Road Brewing was recently acquired by AB InBev but is still brewing their beer with excellence. Enjoy!

# Drink this if You Like: 

Lagers, Pale Ales, Blondes

# Ideal for People who Like:  

The Golden State, Birkenstocks, Surfing  

# Drink While You Are: 

Grilling burgers on an open fire in Yosemite

# Pair With: 

Burgers, Kebabs, anything off the grill.

beers.name: Anchor California Lager
beers.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-_305204_b89247d2b37f4cde5e9d5de7e8bc.jpeg
beers.description:
# Drink this if You Like

Lagers, Pale Ales, Blondes

# Beer Description

Our California Lager is also a single-hop beer, using only fresh, whole Cluster hops, all descended from an old line originally grown in California. Cluster has a long history as a "dual-purpose hop" for both bittering and aroma, which creates a flavor profile like no other. Brewed with San Francisco tap water, fresh from Yosemite, and fermented with our own special strain of lager yeast, our California Lager is kräusened in the traditional manner and lagered in our cellars. The result is a uniquely sessionable lager beer, which is maltier, hoppier, and somewhat stronger than modern American lagers. Its brilliant golden color, lingering effervescence, balanced depth of flavor, distinctive aroma, and smooth finish make this inaugural brew of the Anchor Brewing Zymaster™ Series a delightful tribute to the rich heritage and traditions of California brewing.

# The Boys' Take

A great smooth American lager that is a great way to step into craft beer and away from some of those so called "American Lagers"…

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing. Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today. Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries). The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air. To be honest, we're not sure what effect that has. But it most do something. Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat. The original copper brewing equipment is still there. The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Ideal for People who Like

The Golden State, Birkenstocks, Surfing

# Drink While You Are

Grilling burgers on an open fire in Yosemite

# Pair With

Burgers, Kebabs, anything off the grill.

beers.name: Apocalypse IPA
beers.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-_12786_0b762061e2e3f650c0d8ef37182c.jpeg
beers.description:
# Beer Description:  

A Northwest American-Style IPA. The color comes through as a deep gold with orange hues. Fruity and citrusy hop aroma shines, with hints of pine resin. The four hop flavor dominates, re-enforcing the aroma with more citrus, fruity and piney notes. The malt character is clean and smooth with a unique toasted flavor (thanks to the generous helping of Victory malt), all held together by a firm bitterness. Apocalypse has a medium-bodied mouth feel, finishing crisp and dry. All of this results in a very drinkable IPA

# What you should know: 

Along with the basic Centennial and Cascade hops, Horizon hops here are used to bring bitterness, but without harshness- making Apocalypse as drinkable as possible. Amarillo hops, meanwhile, are all citrus- meaning this beer might even trick you into thinking it’s sweet     

# The Boys’ Take: 

The boys at 10 Barrel made this to be both flavorful and approachable.  It’s not crazy- but after a few sips dammit- you appreciate it.  It’s just a really good, really drinkable IPA.  Cheers to THAT.

# About the Brewer: 

Brew beer. Drink Beer. Have fun doing it.  Those are the mottos of 10 Barrel- and although we don’t do as much of the first one as we’d like, we definitely do numbers two and three a lot- and even we can’t keep up with these guys. And we love their spirit, because, after all, brothers Chris and Jeremy Cox didn’t actually know how to brew when they started the brewery.  They just loved beer, and brought on some of the best in the business to create signature recipes.  This enterprising spirit, plus some damn good beer, led 10 Barrel to be one of the most successful Oregon breweries (a crowded field).  So successful, in fact, that AB/In-Bev/Coors/Mega Beer actually bought them in 2014, meaning more 10 Barrel for everyone!

# Drink if you Like: 

IPAs, DIPAs

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Fun, irreverence, the end of the world

# Drink While You Are: 

Battling aliens or the four horsemen, getting crunk

# Pair With:  

Blue cheese, cheddar, curry, fish, chicken, thai

beers.description:
# Beer Description

This is an aggressive ale. You probably won't like it. It is quite doubtful that you have the taste or sophistication to be able to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth. We would suggest that you stick to safer and more familiar territory–maybe something with a multi-million dollar ad campaign aimed at convincing you it's made in a little brewery, or one that implies that their tasteless fizzy yellow beverage will give you more sex appeal. Perhaps you think multi-million dollar ad campaigns make things taste better. Perhaps you're mouthing your words as you read this.

# What You Should Know

This beer may be feeling itself a little. If you need more details, visit its home page. www.arrogantbastard.com

# The Boy's Take

Don't be scared off by the aggressive title and marketing. What you really get here is healthy (but manageable) dose of flavor. There's a really strong malt flavor here that you'll notice first- a little heavy on the tongue. And then come the hops- BOOM. There's a lot of them, and it's a real bitter, spicy flavor, but one we're sure you'll enjoy… if you're up to it.

# About the Brewer

Stone, located in Escondido, CA, is brash, fun, and serious about beer. Co-founders Greg Koch and Steve Wagner met in 1989 and quickly discovered they both loved brewing. Not so quickly, they decided to open a brewery. Greg was the business man, Steve the brewmaster. They brewed beers that define the West Coast style- adventurous and hop-forward. They released the Arrogant Bastard strong ale (a revolution at the time) and quickly grew a reputation for not being afraid to stand up to the big guys. Along the way, they've become pretty big themselves, now being available almost everywhere. In fact, Stone is one of the top 5000 fastest-growing private companies in the US… and has been for 10 straight years. The icing on the cake? Stone became the first craft brewery to stake its flag in the heard of the beer universe- Germany. Just this year, they announced that they will be opening a brewery in Berlin. Woah.

# Drink this if You Like

Lots of Malts. Lots of Hops

# Ideal for People who Like

Bastards (which is all women if you ask the IT Crowd), not being ashamed to toot your own horn

# Drink While You Are

Feeling smug, needing of a kick in the face

# Pair With

Pork chops, duck tacos, food that can stand up to the Bastard

# Beer Description

Robust and smooth, this full-flavored lager is exceptionably drinkable and pitch black in color.

# What you should know

The emphasis for Schwarzbiers is on dark, roasted malts, mixed with lager yeast, meaning when you get a Schwarzbier, you're really looking at straight malt- no crazy yeast esters and very little bitterness. The earliest documented beer of this type is from 1543, and it's still made in many places in E Germany today.

# The Boy's Take

Smooth and chocolately, Baba has long been an easy-drinking favorite of ours at HQ. We get chocolate and little bit of woodiness and maybe a little bit of that umami taste you get from soy sauce, the one that makes you want it so much.

# About the Brewer

Uinta is in a bit of a strange situation. A successful craft brewer since 1993, Uinta brews a variety of amazing beers, but is based in Salt Lake City, Utah- a state where only beers under 4% ABV are allowed in grocery stores (anything else is treated like liquor). This means that the biggest brewery in the state doesn't even sell a single can in grocery stores in the state! Anyway, Uinta has done a great job despite that obstacle and is well known for well-crafted (often high-grav) beers that are respectful of style while still pushing the envelope. Especially recommended are their IPAs such as Hop Nosh, Dubhe DIPA and Labyrinth Black Ale

# Drink this if You Like

Porters, dark lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

Black sheep, bags of wool, black coffee, chocolate

# Drink While You Are

Hanging out with your boy Schwartz (we know, not quite perfect, but…), trying to be smooth

# Pair With

Rich barbeque, Mexican, dark bread, pretzels, marinated meat

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Back in Black is our newest year-round beer available now in six pack cans and on draft. Brewed like an American IPA but with the addition of rich, dark malts, this beer has all the flavor and hop character you expect with a smooth, mellow finish.

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious, They just have the advantage of pulling it maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs plus a rich, dark taste, stouts, IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

AC/DC, the original Coke, being cool, the "darker side" of things

# Drink While You Are

Trying to stand out, feeling cold but still wanting an IPA

# Pair With

Red meat, BBQ ribs, Burgers, Shepherd's Pie, Wheat Pancakes (why not!)

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Brewed from the late 70s at Burton. In 2000, after Interbrew bought the Bass brand, production was switched to the Ulster brewery in Northern Ireland. In 2003 production and distribution was switched to Latrobe for a 12-18 period after which it reverted to the UK, latterly at InBev's Samlesbury brewery. As of 2012, the US version was being produced at A-B InBev's Baldwinsville brewery.

# What you should know

Extra special bitter is just a term for a British Pale Ale and don't be taken aback by the name! This is nowhere near like an IPA for example. It's sweeter and easy to drink.

# The Boys' Take

It's light and malty, with nice aroma and finishes nice and dry. Just like an ESB should be.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale ales, amber ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Crumpets, high tea, soccer, English pubs

# Drink While You Are

Watching some footy, explaining what an ESB is to someone

# Food Pairings

Burgers, Shepherd's Pie, Shellfish, Fish and Chips, lamb, pizza

# Beer Description

If you have fallen for the IPA style like we have, Big Eye will be a welcome addition to your repertoire. You'll revel in Big Eye's bitter, hoppy flavor thanks to the American Columbus and Centennial hops that are used to flavor and dry hop our flagship IPA. We thank our hops every day that the English loved their bitters—or else the IPA style may not have been born to help the beer survive the journey from Cape Hope to India back in the 18th century

# What you should know

This is your traditional American West Coast IPA- lots of Columbus hops flavor and then dry-hopping with Centennial. Centennial hops are one of our favorites- a nice piney smell and citrusy taste.

# The Boys' Take

Not flashy, so solid. A really nice body of malts holds up the floral tastes that we are desperately seeking. Due to the Centennial dry-hopping, we get a lot of grassy and flowery flavor here.

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers. Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene. Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world. As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out. Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born. Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Double IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Coronado, Grapefruit, the smell of freshly-cut grass

# Drink While You Are

Eating sushi, resting after kiteboarding

# Food Pairings

Sweet Hawaiian fish, Curry, Cured meat

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Our Blood Orange Gose is a tart, refreshing wheat ale that is kettle-soured with lactobacillus and brewed with sea salt and coriander. However, unlike traditional versions of the style, ours features liberal additions of blood oranges during fermentation. This imparts tangy citrus notes that complement the champagne-like flavors, creating a complex and sessionable ale perfect for any occasion.

# What You Need To Know

Gose are sour beers that originated in Goslar, Germany- the style started in the 16th Century, but almost went extinct during WWII!  The style is brewed using salt and coriander and often has a lemony flavor.  Super refreshing.  The addition of the blood orange in this one not only gives Anderson Valley’s Gose more citrus, but also a tangy Orange flavor. 

# The Boys' Take

So you a fan of this whole sour thing, huh?  You can’t go wrong with this one!  Tart. Refreshing.  It’s sour, but not really funky- more tangy and really not that salty.  

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around.  The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987.  After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali.  Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken).  Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene.  Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Like

Goses, Lactobacillus-based beers, Wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Blood oranges, San Pelegrino, friendly bacteria

# Drink While You Are

Looking for crisp, cool refreshment, enjoying a late Spring brunch

# Pair With

Smoked Salmon, Oysters, Pad Thai, Bitter Greens

beers.description:
# Beer Description

A medium-bodied pale ale with a beautiful copper color, a robust head, and the rich flavor of caramel malt.

# What you should know

Boontling is a language used on every Anderson Valley Brewing labels. Spoken by the inhabitants of the Anderson Valley, of which Boonville is the largest town. Boonville was an isolated farming and logging town during the late 1800's. There are a couple different stories about the origin of Boontling. Some say that the language was created by the women, children, and young men in the hop fields and farmlands as a means of entertainment, and that it spread through the region as the kids continued using it when they grew up.

# The Boy's Take

Amber ales are one of those beer styles it's hard to do wrong but Anderson Valley true to form has produced one of the best Amber Ale's around! Not too heavy with caramel maltiness and just a hint of floral hops. A prefect easy drinker.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Red Ales, Amber Lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

Small towns, Local lingo

# Drink While You Are

Finishing up a meditation sesh, looking at something beautiful

# Pair With

Anything off the grill, Pork tenderloin, grilled chicken, burgers.

BREW FREE! OR DIE IPA is brewed with some serious west coast attitude. This aromatic golden IPA starts with three different hops to the nose, quickly balanced by a solid malt backbone supporting the firm bitterness. Our top selling beer at the pub, this IPA starts big and finishes clean leaving you wanting more.

# The Boys' Take

So smooth it might surprise you that this is not a session IPA! A solid brew that is sure to a go to for any hop head!

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious, They just have the advantage of pulling it maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

West Coast IPA's, floral, and citrus.

# Ideal for People who Like

Freedom, Merica, The Black Hills of Wyoming.

# Drink While You Are

Defending the Constitution, Doing anything Revolutionary.

# Pair With

Pork Chops and Apple Sauce! Or anything off the grill.

beers.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-1139170_ff43b_sm.jpeg
beers.description:
# Beer Description

Tune in and hop out with New Belgium Citradelic. Set adrift on a kaleidoscopic wave of hoppiness brought to you by a mystical marriage of Citra hops and tangerine peel, which elevates each sip onto a plane of pure tropical, fruity pleasure. Citradelic’s namesake hop and fruit combine to jam with visions of additional hops like citrusy Mandarina Baveria, tropical Azzaca, and fruity Galazy from a colorful explosion that’s grounded by just a touch of malty sweetness. Bored by the status quo? Expand your palate with a pour of Citradelic. Launching January 2016.

# The Boys’ Take

You can’t beat an IPA with this hop bill in the winter- to take you away to someplace a bit warmer (at least in your mind). Tropical fruit, orchard fruit, and citrus fruit combine in this brew to give you an amazingly hoppy fruit surprise!

# About the Brewer

New Belgium is the third-largest craft brewer in the land (after Sam Adams/Boston Beer and Sierra Nevada), and we love them for it.  Despite their size, you would be hard-pressed to find a throw-away beer in NB’s lineup, even amongst the almost 40 that they have in the bullpen today (that’s by our count, and we’d had a few so please feel free to correct us).  To maintain quality and not slip-up is truly remarkable, considering NB’s range and reach.  If you go to any beer retailer, you are likely to see a lot of New Belgium.  Don’t worry, you can’t go wrong- take a shot on one of their beers- or better yet, we’ll bring you some :)

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

VW Vans, Tie-dye, Bellbottoms. 

# Drink While You Are

Smoking the home grown, Crashing on your friends couch, Walking in a citrus grove. 

# Pair With

Indian, Thai, Vietnamese, Cajun, Mexican, marinara, pesto

beers.name: Evil Twin
beers.description:
# Beer Description:  

This blood-red ale may not be what you might expect from a malty and hoppy craft beer. Evil Twin has a rich malt character, without being overly sweet. It has a huge hop character, without being overly bitter. It is a great example of a bold, rich, balanced craft beer, without being heavy and hard to drink in quantity. Our Evil Twin is only bad because it is too good to resist.

# The Boy’s Take: 

You’d think this beer would be a lot hoppier but it’s really quite balanced and while rich still doesn’t weigh too hard on your palate. The malt and the hops are balanced really well.

# About the Brewer:  

Craft brewers are know for unorthodox names but this one definitely takes it to the next level. Heretic brewing’s “Confessional” (yes that’s right they call their tap room The Confessional) is located in Fairfield California. 

# Drink this if You Like: 

American Strongs, Hoppy Browns, Strong Ales

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Inciting a riot, Taking or religious types

# Drink While You Are: 

On trial, About to get burned at the steak.

# Pair With:

beers.name: Fleur de Houblon (Summer Ale)
beers.description:
# Beer Description

Nothing is more evocative of summer than the beautiful aroma of flowers, and the favored flowers of brewers are hops. Our brand new summer ale, Fleur de Houblon (Hop Flowers), is brewed to bring the many elements of summer into a refreshing and easy-to-drink Belgian-style ale. Fleur de Houblon is a rich gold color with distinct floral hops in the aroma that follow through in the taste. Whole-cone Bravo hops are used to impart their earthy, fruity, and floral aromas and flavors. The body and flavor are clean and dry, with pleasing complexity and spicy notes from both primary and secondary fermentation with our unique Ommegang house yeast. 

# What you should know: 

Note this beer isn’t what many would consider “hoppy”, in other words bitter- but there is a depth of flavor coming from hops, Bravo hops in this instance.  Bravo hops aren’t aggressive- they just round out the flavor.  In fact, you might compare them to using rosewater- just the faintest floral edge.     

# The Boys’ Take: 

Balanced and refreshing, this is a summer beer for people who don’t want fruit juice or sweet wheat in their beer (not that there’s anything wrong with that).  Soft, grainy malts finish with floral, slightly bittersweet hops.  We likey.

# About the Brewer: 

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashioned after old-school Belgian traditions.  The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY.  Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition).  Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery.   In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast.  Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US.  In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink if you Like: 

Victory Summer Love, Saisons, Blonde Ales

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Crushability, balance, the summer

# Drink While You Are: 

Indulging in a summer fling, judging other summer beers

# Pair With:  

Asparagus, cream and butter pasta, Chicken Fracase

beers.name: Go West! IPA™

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Made with 2-row pale barley malt and dry-hopped with a unique blend of 4 American hops. Its mouthwateringly complex aromas of citrus, pine, and the tropics; spiky bitterness; gleaming golden color; and clean finish unite to create this singular 24-karat IPA

# What You Should Know

Anchor IPA is made with 2-row barley malt and fresh whole-cone hops, its bright amber color, distinctively complex aroma, spiky bitterness, malty depth, and clean finish unite to create a uniquely flavorful, memorable, and timeless craft IPA. 

# The Boys’ Take
  
An excellent traditional IPA brewed on the west coast but not quite a “west coast” IPA. An excellent combination of rich malt, light citrus, and juniper this IPA hits the spot for any hop head and is a must try to anyone new to IPAs! 

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing.  Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today.  Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries).  The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air.  To be honest, we’re not sure what effect that has.  But it most do something.  Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat.  The original copper brewing equipment is still there.  The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, IPAs, DIPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Originality, tradition, the best beer to come out of the 70s

# Drink While You Are 

Riding an Elephant, At a bizarre in Bombay 

# Pair With 

Chicken, Cheeseburgers, Spicy BBQ, Chicken Tikka Masala.

# Beer Description

Our IPA recalls a time when ales shipped from England to India were highly hopped to preserve their distinct taste during the long journey. The result, quite simply a hop lover's dream. And this classic ale adds a fruity aroma, set off by a dry malt middle, to ensure that the long hop finish is one you'll remember.

# What You Need to Know

Wines and beers were frequently altered to make the long voyages across the ocean.In the case of beer adding more hops preserved beer for the long journey. Alpha acids in the hops are responsible for bittering the beer, the beta acids have been found to counteract and delay the inevitable effects of bacterial spoilage, thereby giving beer a longer shelf life.

# The Boys' Take

Every craft brewery needs a great standard India Pale Ale and Goose Island has done an excellent job crafting their offering. This IPA has a great mix of floral and earthy hops that's well balanced with Pale Malts.

# About the Brewer

Goose Island is Chicago's microbrewery, launched in 1988 by founder John Hall, just returned from a European tour. More than just making good craft beer, Hall advocated for it, helping bring consciousness of this new revolution to one of the US's largest cities. This meant growth, and by 1995, it was time for another brewery. Along the way, Hall had built smaller pilot beer labs and 143,000 sqft of barrel space for barrel-aging beers. This was revolutionary, and it got Goose Island its name, especially for the Bourbon Country Barrel-Aged Stout (released once a year on Black Friday and notorious for creating long lines far from the shopping malls). But eventually there was a cap to the growth, and Annheiser-Busch came calling. Yes, Goose Island has been owned by A-B for several years and that has meant… a lot more Goose Island. Most would agree, the quality of the beer is still top-notch, you just can get Goose Island in a lot more places, thanks to A-B. And there's nothing wrong with that.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, IPA's

# Ideal for People who Like

Working for the East India Trading Company

# Drink While You Are

Sailing the Seven Seas

# Pair With

Curries, Chicken, Pork, Blue Cheese, Aged Gouda

# Beer Description

Unfiltered Belgian White, flavored with coriander and orange peel, creating a sweet & sour taste.

# What You Need to Know

Belgian Wits are distinguished by the tradition of using what is known as the gruit, rather than hops, as the main flavor source. Gruit (which can contain hops) is typically a mix of coriander, orange and hops, and therefore the typical Wit taste is closer to sour and a lot less bitter.

# The Boy's Take

Mhmm, this is like a mulled cider, with heavy clove notes and a pretty heavy taste. A little spicy and citrusy

# About the Brewer

Perhaps they had too much time on their hands. Or they were sick of the sacramental wine. Maybe it was divine inspiration? We'll never know for sure. What we do know is that the Hoegaarden monks were the first to discover the unique recipe for wheat beer around 1445.

# Drink this if You Like

Wheat beer, Dubbels

# Ideal for People who Like

Belgians, orange juice, cider, cloves

# Drink While You Are

Touring some abbeys

# Pair With

Vinaigrette, goat cheese, poultry, fish, apple pie

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Wonderful complex flavos, like no other, simply a great tasting IPA. It's balanced, strong malt backbone, citrusy nose, with hints of pine and grass.

# What you should know

Uinta originally named this beer "Hop Notch"- meaning still unknown to us- but quickly ran into trademark trouble and had to change the name to Hop Nosh (which actually makes more sense to us, as you are "noshing" on some hops with this drink).

# The Boy's Take

Where the guys at Uinta get this is right is by provide a solid backbone of malt to hold up the mostly citrusy hops. You'll taste bitterness midway through this drink, and then at the end, it'll be a bit of earthy, roasty taste (just a bit). And you'll want another.

# About the Brewer

Uinta is in a bit of a strange situation. A successful craft brewer since 1993, Uinta brews a variety of amazing beers, but is based in Salt Lake City, Utah- a state where only beers under 4% ABV are allowed in grocery stores (anything else is treated like liquor). This means that the biggest brewery in the state doesn't even sell a single can in grocery stores in the state! Anyway, Uinta has done a great job despite that obstacle and is well known for well-crafted (often high-grav) beers that are respectful of style while still pushing the envelope. Especially recommended are their IPAs such as Hop Nosh, Dubhe DIPA and Labyrinth Black Ale

# Drink this if You Like

Citrusy, well-balanced IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

The finer points of trademark law, Utah, vegetarian snacks

# Drink While You Are

Feeling parched, losing an argument

# Pair With

Party food, salsa, cheeseburgers

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Hop-Heads, your dreams have come true! Hop Ottin' is Boontling for "hardworking hops," and they're surely hard at work in this brew. Hop Ottin' starts with a strong floral aroma, which winds into a deep and complex body. In an intriguing balance, honey-drenched malts coat rich hop undertones. At length, the hops prevail, with a satisfyingly crisp finish. Hop Ottin' bites like a cankicky bluetail (Hop Ottin' bites like a rattlesnake looking for a fight.)

# What you should know

The ingredients in this one are simple- just two types of hops and three malts, but it's all about the proper balance to make the malts stand up and the hops shine through

# The Boy's Take

This is an interesting one. There's some grapefruit smell, but the surprising element is the syrupy sweetness that makes this quite pleasant to drink, with a hoppy hook at the end

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Imperial IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Otters, country-folk, California

# Drink While You Are

Walking through the valley, looking out over the Pacific Coast Highway

# Pair With

Garlic fries, curry, mahi fish tacos, carrot cake

# Beer Description

Affiliated with the Nectar Ales experience through
shared origins at Humboldt Brewing Company, Hemp Ale is a one-of-a-kind
brew that boasts an incredibly rich profile and unique herb-accented
flavor that is attributable to the incorporation of hemp seeds into the
brewing process. A wonderful brown ale full of complexity Hemp Ale is
great with food or by itself. American hops create a perfect balance to
the darker malts used in this brew. This brown ale is the Gold Medal
winner for first place in its category at both the 1999 and 2000
California State Fair Craft Brewing Competitions

# The Boys’ Take

Rosty and dark with just enough body for a brown
ale Humboldt’s brown ale is right on the money. Notes of chocolate, nut,
and caramel malts a really solid brown ale.

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be
all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft
microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern
California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their
carbon footprint, and who doesn’t love that? In 2005, the little
Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total
Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale
after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex,
malty beers from these nature lovers!

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Brown Ales, Porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a picnic, refilling your bird feeder

# Pair With

Beef stew, Roast Lamb, Shepherd’s Pie.

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Our India Pale Ale exhibits a complex hop aroma, largely due to the generous usage of Cascade and Centennial hops, as well as a subtle malt character from the various malts used to achieve the wonderful balance exhibited in a world-class IPA. San Diego has become world renown for the wonderful and flavorful beers produced here – and India Pale Ales are no exception. Our national award winning interpretation of the style reflects both the history of IPA and the American variation of this distinct beverage. We hope you enjoy it!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Imperial IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Award Winning beers, Wonder Bread

# Drink While You Are

Sitting down, Missioning

# Pair With

Traditional Mexican Fare, Grilled Meats

# Beer Description

Named after Coronado Island, our original India Pale Ale is a liquid expression of hometown pride. Cascade, Chinook, and Columbus hops combine to provide an explosive burst of piney bitterness and lucioius notes of apricot, grapefruit, and mango that are sure to envoke imagery of swinging palms and sun-kissed shores.

# What You Should Know

The Islander IPA swings for a tropical home run. All three of the C's (the hop varieties used here) come with a fruity, juicy taste.

# The Boy's Take

This one is sweeter than most IPAs, with a light body that does surprisingly well to not taste like alcohol at 7%. A the finish, it really does carry a little bit like a nice Tequila Sunrise, with some citrusy sweetness.

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America's greatest beach (Coronado) and their first keg delivery was straight to the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000 barrels a year, and we can't wait for an ever-greater selection to be available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit, the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Drink this if You Like

West Coast IPAs, Tropical Drinks

# Ideal for People who Like

Mojitos, Pina Coladas, Sunbathing

# Drink While You Are

Finding your beach, doing some California Dreaming

# Food Pairings

Curried food, Thai food, peppery cheese, sharp cheddar

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Kellerweis is one of the only American Hefeweizens made using the traditional Bavarian style of open fermentation. This difficult and labor-intensive technique adds uncommon depth and flavor complexity. Our hazy-golden hefeweizen is deeply flavorful, refreshing and perfect for a sunny day. To serve, pour two-thirds into a glass, swirl and pour the rest.

# What You Should Know

Open fermentation leads to the development of additional "esters", or acids that are created and lead to fruity, soft flavors.  The additional warmth and space in open fermentation is perfect for development of these flavors.

# The Boys’ Take

One of the best wheat beers in the US, the Kellerweis is simply a pleasure to drink- sweet first, but with a well-developed sense of flavor- light cloves and just a little bit of banana

# About the Brewer

The third-largest craft brewer in the US, Sierra Nevada has proven that it belongs at the very top of the rankings since 1980.  From the beginning, Sierra Nevada beer has been a celebration of spicy American hops, and they’ve never backed down from that.  And they’ve earned their upper-tier position by forging a path that in 1980 barely existed.  Hops were hard to find.  Brewery equipment didn’t come on a micro scale.  Then they came up with the Pale Ale, which was instrumental in bringing the West Coast style to the mainstream.  Finally in 1987, Sierra Nevada moved into downtown Chico and setup shop.  Now they are a N. California fixture and also have a brewery in the works in Asheville, NC.  To this day, Sierra Nevada is still synonymous with hoppy, fresh beer, and we hope that never changes

# Drink this if You Like

Hefeweizens, American Wheat ales, Tripels

# Ideal for People who Like

Germany, words that begin with K, yeast

# Drink While You Are

Enjoing a warm day, going on a hike

# Pair With

Fruit Salad, Grilled Salmon, Bratwurst, Brie, Camembert

# Beer Description

Originally brewed in 1975 to commemorate Paul Revere's ride, this brew is a heavily hopped ale (Cascade hops) with a copper color and a hoppy nose.

# What You Should Know

Liberty Ale is single hopped and dry-hopped, two concepts that were revolutionary in 1975 when this beer first appeared. Then the beer is aged in casks with bungs to promote natural carbonation.

# The Boys' Take

Is this a Pale Ale? Is it an IPA? Since this one was invented sooo early, it sorta defies classification as either. It was a true trend-setter with its emphasis on dry-hopping. It's not going to be too bitter, but does have a nice kick to it. Real grapefruity!

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing. Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today. Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries). The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air. To be honest, we're not sure what effect that has. But it most do something. Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat. The original copper brewing equipment is still there. The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales and IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Originality, tradition, the best beer to come out of the 70s

# Drink While You Are

Celebrating being American, or being a blacksmith, or riding horses at midnight

# Pair With

Chicken, nutty cheeses, salad, fish, Italian, BBQ

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Our Longfin Lager has become one of the go-to beers with the team at the brewery. A solidly balanced Helles inspired Lager with a clean, slightly hoppy finish that could easily fit in at any German beer garden. We think it's perfect for enjoying on the beach, the boat or anywhere else you can put an ice chest full of bee

# What you should know

Lager can seem like a derogatory term due to its reminder of American mass-produced beers, but actually, lagering is simply one of the oldest types of beer technology. Lager yeasts ferment at a lower temperature than ale yeasts and brew more purely. This can mean more consistency and smoother, if less complex taste. A Helles Lager, such as this one, is characteristically German- it's more malt-forward than it's cousin the Pilsener

# The Boys' Take

This is style that isn't going to bring any wild flavors to the table, but this is a very well-crafted example. The malt flavor is nice and well-balanced. The hop flavors are going to be kinda traditional German flavors and mostly subdued.

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers. Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene. Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world. As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out. Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born. Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea

# Drink this if You Like

Pilseners, lagers, blonde ales, Kolschs

# Ideal for People who Like

Fishing, the Beach (but without Corona), San Diego

# Drink While You Are

Fishing, at the beach, telling a fish tale

# Food Pairings

White Fish, Citrus, Cantalope

A really great west coast style IPA. The name says it all with nectar fruit notes a kiss of hop bitterness and some beautiful floral aromas if you like a good IPA you'll love this one!

They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their carbon footprint, and who doesn't love that? # Beer Description

Our spiced California style Wit is both refreshing
and complex. Brewed with wheat, coriander, California orange peel and
local orange blossom honey. From the first sip to the last you’ll find
subtle flavors of bread, spice, citrus and a thirst quenching orange
honey finish.

# The Boys’ Take

This is an aggressive take on a witbier, with lots
of orange peel and coriander flavor and a malty finish.

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island
roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America’s
greatest beach (Coronado) and their first keg delivery was straight to
the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick
Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look
for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000
barrels a year, and we can’t wait for an ever-greater selection to be
available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit,
the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Drink if you Like

Witbiers, Belgian ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Going over the top, getting aggressive

# Drink While You Are

Charging it up, dishing out some orange slices

# Pair With

Shellfishes, mussels, omlets

# Beer Description

Our first lager produced with the 20 bbl brewhouse. This pilsner is a clear golden color. Four additions of Saaz hops lend a spicy-floral hop component.

# What You Need to Know

Both German and Czech styles of pilsener developed as rivals in Europe, and although Germans are known more for their pilseners, we'd venture to say that the Czech version has done pretty well for itself all on its own.

# The Boy's Take

This one is all-malt, no additives of corn or rice to water this down, and you can tell- there's real flavor here.

# About the Brewer

Oskar Blues is quickly becoming a North Carolina favorite, in large part due to the fact that they opened a second base of operations near Asheville recently. This means their beer is even fresher than ever before, with the cans having to travel just two short hours down 74 to Charlotte. Although their beer is easy to miss in the little cans, Oskar Blues has generated quite a following and are ready to celebrate their 12th anniversary in 2014 (the original brewery is in tiny Lyons, CO)

# Drink this if You Like

Pilseners

# Ideal for People who Like

Mama, self-medication

# Drink While You Are

Playing with your golden retriever Rex

# Beer Description

Abita Purple Haze is a crisp, American style wheat beer with fresh raspberries added during secondary fermentation. Subtle coloration, fruity aroma and tartly sweet taste.

# What you Need to Know

This beer is a lager, meaning is fermented with lager yeast and kept cold (45-50 degrees) during fermentation. This keeps the flavors crisp and clear (instead of influences by other flavors in the air). The raspberries are added after the beer is bottled.

# About the Brewer

Abita was founded in 1986, and is in many ways the quintessential Southern beer. Brewed in Abita Springs, LA (40 minutes north of New Orleans), Abita makes a wide range of brews, some of which are perfect for pairing with seersucker and sticky nights- and that's something we need here in the South. Another added benefit is the pure, deep water from Abita Springs- this is the last little bit that kicks Abita beer "up a notch!" Most Abita beers are light drinking and perfect for summer nights, and are made with all-natural, high-quality ingredients.

# Drink this if You Like

Smooth lagers, sweet/tangy beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Louisiana, raspberries, Jimmy Hendricks, Seer sucker

# Drinking While you Are

Boogying, or at a hoedown

# Pair with

Salad, light dessert, chocolate, Brie, mascarpone, citrus

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Rare Vos is flemmish for "Sly Fox," and the name of one of Brussels' great cafes. It has a sweetly fruity malt character and yeasty spiciness. A fine dose of yeast permits the beer to mature and mellow in the bottle.

# What you should know

The name is inspired by the cafés (such as Rare Vos) that serve these soft, yeasty amber ales all throughout Belgium. This one of the maltier brews on offer for Ommegang and features Styrian Goulding hops.

# The Boys' Take

Rare Vos will remind you a little of cherries and other dark fruit as you sip it, but not in an overpowering way. Most of the flavors are mellow and soft, with the yeast flavor definitely still shining through. It remains light throughout and finishes dry. Sorta like a gassed water you might be given at a Flemish café.

# About the Brewer

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashion after old-school Belgian traditions. The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY. Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition). Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery. In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast. Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US. In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink if you Like

Dubbels, lambics, Amber ales

# Ideal for People who Like

European cafes and checkered tablecloths, San Pellegrino

# Drink While You Are

Eating moules frites or Belgian waffles, seeking a sophisticated beverage.

# Pair With

Cheese, rich desserts, risotto, mustard greens, chili

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Boasting a ruby hue and an exquisite floral aroma, Red Nectar is a robust yet elegant brew with distinctive accents of toasted malt, caramel, spice and residual sweetness. The beer that started it all… Red Nectar was considered a strange bird when it was first released in 1987. After all, where did a robust, handcrafted all-natural amber ale fit into the massive flock of American industrial lagers? Answer: it didn't. So it blazed its own trail, helping set the pace for the craft brew revolution. Enjoy Red Nectar for its dazzling reddish copper hue, original flavors and caramel spice accents

# The Boys' Take

Flavorful, tasty and malty. This one starts sweet with the smell and the taste- maybe a little bit like a snack of fruit, then there's a spice taste. Finally, you may feel some slight fruity hops hit the back of your throat. Amber ales are normally a relatively tame bunch, but this one has some complexity.

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their carbon footprint, and who doesn't love that? In 2005, the little Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex, malty beers from these nature lovers!

# Drink this if You Like

Amber ales, porters, doppelbocks, smooth-drinking beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a picnic, refilling your bird feeder

# Pair With

Chicken, vegetables, hamburgers, sandwiches

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Malt and hops are beautifully married in this full-bodied, copper-red Pale Ale. Red Seal Ale is generously hopped in the traditional manner for a long, spicy finish.

# What you should know

Pale ales grew up as a term for the strongest ales carried in English pubs. More than other English beers, lighter malts in the pale ale allowed hops to do most of the talking. The copper malts in Red Seal Ale give it a dry, toasted feel, extenuating the punch that the bitter hops bring.

# The Boy's Take

The darker malts in this beer make us lean more towards a hoppy amber ale, but who are we to argue with North Coast? The malts here are slightly sweet, and the hops aren't overwhelming but instead nicely balanced and herby, which balances quite well with the more robust body. We like it.

# About the Brewer

North Coast brewing is a veteran in the craft beer scene. In 2015, they don't care about being cool, trendy or buzz-worthy. Just a group of craftsmen concentrating on making excellent beer. We might suggest a slight update to the website, but we don't suppose these guys care. Mark Ruedrich started North Coast in 1988 on the picturesque Mendocino coast (north of San Francisco), just down Hwy 1 from Mendocino brewing. Mark doesn't seem to be about flashy new releases, fancy labels and hot styles. Instead, North Coast has a broad range, one that hasn't changed much in years (although more recently NCB has resurrected the old ACME brewing label from 1800's San Francisco). You may know the Old Rasputin Imperial Stout. Drink that, but we also recommend Old Stock Ale and the Old No. 38 Stout.

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Pacific sea mammals, whiskers, Sea World

# Drink While You Are

Sitting on a rocky beach, sun bathing, avoiding Killer Whales

# Pair With

Quesadillas, salsa, steak and other red meat, spinach salad, andouille

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Samuel Adams Boston Lager® is the best example of the fundamental characteristics of a great beer, offering a full, rich flavor that is both balanced and complex. It is brewed using a decoction mash, a time consuming, traditional four vessel brewing process discarded by many contemporary brewers. This process brings forth a rich sweetness from the malt that makes it well worth the effort. Samuel Adams Boston Lager® also uses only the finest of ingredients including two row barley, as well as German Noble aroma hops. The exclusive use of two row barley not only imparts a full, smooth body but also gives the beer a wide spectrum of malt flavor ranging from slightly sweet to caramel to slightly roasted. The Noble hops varieties, Hallertau Mittelfruh and Tettnang Tettnanger, add a wide range of floral, piney and citrus notes, which are present from the aroma, through the flavor, to the lingering smooth finish. We take great pride in the Noble hops used in our beers. They are hand selected by Jim Koch and our other brewers from the world's oldest hops growing area. Among the world's most expensive, they cost twenty times as much as other hops.

# What you should know

This was the beer that some say started it all. It was Boston Beer (Sam Adams) very first beer, and one of the first that lead the revolution of using the highest quality ingredients and brewed to a premium quality.

# The Boys' Take

It's been such a long time, it's easy to overlook the old Boston Lager, but there's something to be said for the straight-forward, traditional taste of the beer that "started it all"

# About the Brewer

Boston Beer (aka Sam Adams) is the 300-pound gorilla in any craft beer conversation. In fact, the official definition of "craft beer" was changed in 2010 to make sure Sam Adams was considered craft beer, when they first brewed more than 2 million barrels. Their 2013 revenues were more than 3 times the second-biggest brewer. So yeah, we're talking a different ball game. This makes Sam Adams a divisive topic in the craft beer world. If you listen to Boston Beer, they are still a great innovator and help open a bigger market for craft beer with their big budget and TV ad campaigns. If you ask the hopheads, they are an unimaginative, lumbering giant that deserves to be treated like one of the big boys. We still think they make good beer, and if we know you'll like it, we'll bring you some

# Drink if you Like

Lagers, old school beers, easy-drinking beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Oldies but goodies, the 80s, American patriots

# Drink While You Are

Planning a tea party perhaps?

# Pair With

BBQ, ribs, calamari

beers.description:
# Beer Description

A style of beer curiously born on the foggy shores
of Father Junipero Serra’s first founding mission. Our own vigorous
entry is one rebellious IPA, quick on the trigger, and brimming with a
bounty of hop ingenuity. This is a big, bold, brazen beer, a restless
vision of a new America.

# The Boy’s Take

This is a very west coasty double IPA. Plenty of
hops and malt perfectly blending malt sweetness and citrusy goodness. If
you haven’t tried this one you’re in for a treat!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each. We recommend the
Dark Seas Imperial Stout and also their Pils and Helles lagers.

# Drink this if You Like

Double IPAs, Imperial IPA, IPA

# Ideal for People who Like

Shipwrecks, architecture

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying 24/7 sun, sailing the open seas,
channeling your inner conquistador

# Pair With

Chimichangas, Pad Thai, Mango Chutney.

# Beer Description

Smithwick's is Ireland's number one ale. Its exceptional taste, distinctive colour and purity of ingredients make it unique. Its rich, satisfying taste has earned it five gold medals in the famous Monde Selection Beer Tasting Competition. Smithwick's is produced using the finest hops and special roasted, malted barley.

# What you should know

TheSmithwicks are an Irish family that have been brewing beer in Kilkenny, Ireland since the 1700s. Over a long course of ups and downs and near extinction on many occasions (which seems like a familiar Irish story), Smithwick's has survived and is now one of the most successful beers of Ireland.

# The Boys' Take

Sweet and totally quaffable, we like this one as the start to a night at the pub sometimes. The flavor is very sweet and malty with very little bitterness at all.

# About the Brewer

Well, Smithwick's is owned by the same company as Guinness at this point, but the family brewery has a long history, starting in Kilkenny, Ireland with John Smithwick, who established the brewery but wasn't allowed to legally do trade under his name (he was a Catholic, and Catholics were banned). Successive generations of Smithwicks continued on the tradition, always exploring new markets for their beer and finally reaching Irish Americans in the 1950s.

# Drink this if You Like

Brown Ales, Red Ales, Blonde Ales, Dark Lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

Quick tempers, repressed feelings, potatoes, ruddy complexions

# Drink While You Are

At a pub, taking a break from Jameson

# Food Pairings

Bangers and Mash, rustic British or Irish food, cabbage

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Look up "hops" in the dictionary and you'll see a picture of Stone IPA! "Dry-hopped" for an extra two weeks, this unique process gives our IPA its bountiful hop aroma and rich hop flavor. A full 70+ IBUs (International Bitterness Units) creates this beer's crisp and refreshing bitter character.

# What You Should Know

The "India" in IPA is from the extra hops needed to send British Pale Ales across the ocean to India without them spoiling. When normal Pale Ales won't do- send an Indian Pale Ale. This was one the first full-time, widely-available IPAs

# The Boy's Take

Still standing as one of the IPAs out there on the market, the Stone IPA usually starts with a sweet touch and then quickly moves into sharp, piney bitterness. But it goes down smooth, even with a long, dry finish.

# About the Brewer

Stone, located in Escondido, CA, is brash, fun, and serious about beer. Co-founders Greg Koch and Steve Wagner met in 1989 and quickly discovered they both loved brewing. Not so quickly, they decided to open a brewery. Greg was the business man, Steve the brewmaster. They brewed beers that define the West Coast style- adventurous and hop-forward. They released the Arrogant Bastard strong ale (a revolution at the time) and quickly grew a reputation for not being afraid to stand up to the big guys. Along the way, they've become pretty big themselves, now being available almost everywhere. In fact, Stone is one of the top 5000 fastest-growing private companies in the US… and has been for 10 straight years. The icing on the cake? Stone became the first craft brewery to stake its flag in the heard of the beer universe- Germany. Just this year, they announced that they will be opening a brewery in Berlin. Woah.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Double IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

The original, West Coast brews, San Diego

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a meal on the beach, starting your happy hour right.

# Beer Description:  

A Crisp Citrus Beer with a hint of Tangerine.

# What you Need to Know:

This beer is a lager, meaning is fermented with lager yeast and kept cold (45-50 degrees) during fermentation.  This keeps the flavors crisp and clear (instead of influences by other flavors in the air).  Tangerine and citrus aromas come through strongly.

# About the Brewer:  

The Lost Coast Brewery and Café began with a dream.  In 1986 Barbara Groom, a pharmacist wondered what it would require to start a brewpub.  After years honing her skills home brewing, planning and studying scores of pubs throughout England & Wales Barbara was ready to transform the dream into a reality.
Since its humble beginning in 1990, the brewery has outgrown not just its original facility in the Pythian Castle, but has also outgrown the site it moved to in 1993 just down the street. After a long successful 25 years and breaking two production records in 2005 with 24,000 barrels, and 2009 with over 50,000 barrels, the brewery is now located at the south end of Eureka, California in a brand new state of the art facility. Barbara Groom designed it to not only make exceptional brews in, but to be open for the public to enjoy as well, opening Summer 2015. Currently the new facility is brewing at a 90,000-barrel capacity and is still working to brew to greater heights!

# Drink this if You Like: 

Smooth lagers, sweet/tangy beer

# Ideal for People who Like: 

Boating without a GPS, Fruit Ninja

# Drinking While you Are: 

Looking for Land, Lounging under Palm Fronds

# Pair with: 

Fruit Salad, Hawaiian Pizza, Grilled Snapper with Mango Chutney

# Beer Description: 

There is no beautifier of complexion, or form, or behavior, like the wish to scatter joy and not pain around us. Crisp Lager has nothing to hide behind - no makeup to cover up any flaws. Raw ingredients and their essence, full and unabated...uninhibited...CRISP

# What You Need to Know: 

Pilseners originated in the Czech Republic, believe it or not, but once the style was adopted to Germany, the German brewers slightly adopted the style to have a bit more body and show a bit less spicy hops. Sixpoints doesn’t define which style they’re aiming for, but we tend to think of this more like a Czech pils.

# The Boys’ Take: 

Super dry and refreshing, with a pleasant burst of hopiness at the end.  Balanced, but with a suprising amount of hops in there.

# About the Brewer:  

Sixpoint Brewing is legit, and our Chief Design Officer, Sam loves their website. Plus, they have those Red Bull-style, thinner cans, which is different. Andrew Brownstein and Shane Welch hail from Brooklyn, although much of the beer is brewed upstate. They came on the scene in 2004 and the skinny cans came in 2011.  What’s in the logo, you ask? It’s a mixture of a hexagram and a nautical star.

# Drink this if You Like: 

Lagers, German styles, Pilsners

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Wafers, freshly cleaned sheets

# Drink While You Are: 

Travelling the German-Czech border

Potato wedges, fried chicken, caprese salad

# Beer Description

Abita Turbodog is a dark brown ale brewed with Willamette hops and a combination of British pale, crystal and chocolate malts. This combination gives Turbodog its rich body and color and a sweet chocolate-toffee like flavor.

# What you Need to Know

The Turbodog was actually originally released as a special brew, but popular response was so positive Abita decided to keep it around full-time

# The Boy's Take

(In slow jam voice) This one's smooooth baby.   The taste you' re going to get here is almost entirely malts, and those malts roll nicely on the tongue.    It ' s not super sweet, just the taste of delicious barley.

# About the Brewer

Abita was founded in 1986, and is in many ways the quintessential Southern beer.  Brewed in Abita Springs, LA (40 minutes north of New Orleans), Abita makes a wide range of brews, some of which are perfect for pairing with seersucker and sticky nights- and that's something we need here in the South.  Another added benefit is the pure, deep water from Abita Springs- this is the last little bit that kicks Abita beer "up a notch!"  Most Abita beers are light drinking and perfect for summer nights, and are made with all-natural, high-quality ingredients.

# Drink this if You Like

Brown ales, Porters

Jambalaya, Brits at Mardi Gras, Dogs with Jetpacks

Seducing someone (we have been watching a lot of The Americans recently although no, they don't usually use beer to seduce their victims)

# Beer Description

A refreshing example of an India Pale Ale from the
master brewers at Belhaven. The blend of Cascade and Challenger hops
combine to produce an abundance of fresh hop aroma that preludes a
bitter-dry taste explosion. Crafted from nearly three centuries of
brewing heritage at Scotland’s oldest independent brewery, this ale from
Belhaven will have your taste buds tingling.

# The Boy’s Take

One of the oldest breweries in Scotland still
brewing some of the best traditional beers and also setting the pace for
new Scottish brews. A solid IPA done in more of an American style with
notes of lemon grass and juniper.

# About the Brewer

Belhaven brewing can trace it roots all the way
back to 1719 when the first documentation can be found though many of
the structures of the brewery date back even further. Belhaven was
passed down to family unit 1993 when it was purchased by Greene King.
Belhaven’s most recognizable characters is Belhaven Bill a portly
fisherman that first became the face of Belhaven in 1950.

# Drink this if You Like

English IPAs, IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Kilts, Braveheart, New school meets old
school

Preparing for a kilt-tilting contest, Fishing
Loch Ness

beers.description:
# Beer Description:  

An instant classic, Union Jack is the recipient of numerous awards including back to back wins at the Great American Beer Festival. Union Jack is abound with hop aroma and character. In fact this well balanced, west coast IPA is dry hopped 3 separate times, each lot giving it more and more of the grapefruit citrus hop aroma and flavor it is known for. Overall it utilizes over 4 pounds of pacific northwest hops per barrel.

# The Boys’ Take: 

This is a Californian IPA. Bright auburn color, some sweet malts and then the rich, tangy flavors of pine and citrus- tasty!

# About the Brewer:  

Firestone Walker is located in Paso Robles, California a location more known for its wine production than its brewing. Started in 1996 by brother-in-laws Adam Firestone (yes he’s from the Firestone tire family) and David Walker, Firestone Walker is one of the biggest breweries in California. Firestone walkerowns another brewery, Humboldt Brewing, and is partially owned by Duvel Brewing from Belgium.

# Drink if you Like: 

IPAs, fruit-forward beers

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Breezes, palm trees, the crash of the waves on the shore

# Drink While You Are: 

Going to your happy place

# Drink this if You Like

Wheats, kolschs

# Beer Description

Nothing refreshes you more than this naturally cloudy wheat beer with its wonderful yeasty fragrance and taste. Goes well with dishes that do not have too intensive a flavour, especially that Bavarian speciality 'Weisswurst' or white sausage.

# What You Should Know

Although they are normally associated with Belgium, there are monasteries in Germany too!  Weihenstephaner is actually one of the world’s oldest breweries, but instead of Beligan strong ales and abbey ales, you can find here pale lagers and wheat ales.  There is a filtered version of this beer available as well call, considered a Kirstalweizen

# The Boy's Take

Now this is a hefeweizen done correctly.  The wheat grain adds some heft and flavor, but it’s not syrupy sweet or strangely acidic.  Nope, just weighty enough to make the beer satisfying, but soft enough to make it really drinkable.

# About the Brewer

Weihenstephan actually has a claim (no really) to be the oldest brewery in the world- they have manuscripts dating to the 700s (!) talking about hop gardening occurring on the grounds of the monastery.  The actual business of what we would call beer probably started a little bit later, but regardless, these guys know what they are doing, and have been at it for quite a while.  Eventually, the monastery was secularized, and actually converted into a brewing school along with a production brewery!  The wheat beers are some of the world, so if you like those types, we suggest not missing a chance to check them out.

# Ideal for People who Like

German engineering, the Middle Ages, Friar Tuck

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying some wurst, hiking in the alps

# Pair With

Weisswurst, poultry, cheese

beers.description:
# Beer Description

A truly authentic Belgian style wheat or "white" ale, this Rascal is unfiltered (yup, that's yeast on the bottom) and cleverly spiced with coriander and Curacao orange peel producing a refreshingly fruity thirst quencher.

# What you should know

Witbiers (from the Belgian word for "white") are one of the most traditional Belgian styles, and didn't begin to become popular in the US until the introduction of Blue Moon (by Miller Coors, ironically) in the early 2000s. The Curacao orange hails from the island of the same name (actually a part of the Dutch kingdom) and its peel has been used in the last century to spice up Belgian whites. This variety of orange is actually way too bitter to eat, but the pungency of its peel makes for a great counter-balance to the soft, wheat-y malt of the beer.

# The Boys' Take

This is soft and citrusy and a little heavier than some other white beers. This is what we would say is just pleasant to drink- almost velvet in the mouth and sweet to the tongue.

# About the Brewer

Adam Avery started Avery Brewery in 1993 in Boulder, CO. It was bold at the time to open a brewery, and Avery started small. However, now today is established solidly as a quality brewer out of the brewery mecca of Denver/Boulder. Avery is committed to making original beer… and not just what everybody wants. This means that it hasn't had the same commercial success, but also means it gets to keep a solid reputation with the experts. Some of the best aggressive beers come from here- especially the seasonal Dictator series- which contains traditional classic styles on steroids. If like a drop-kick to the face of fresh hops in the springtime, check out The Maharaja- an Imperial IPA.

# Drink this if You Like

Unfiltered beer, Belgians, wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Citrusy drinks, comfort-down mattresses, playful devils

# Drink While You Are

Kicking back with an orange slice, up to some minor mischief

# Pair With

Spicy food such as thai or Mexican, blackened fish, ceviche

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Ommegang Witte, a traditional Belgian-style wheat ale with whispers of sweet orange and a touch of tart lemon. Soft and seductive.

# What You Should Know

A very highly rated Witbeir. If you like Blue Moon, you’ll love this. Brewed in the Belgian-style, so be sure to look for the Orange peel and coriander flavors. Serve in a tumbler or a weizen.

# About the Brewer

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashion after old-school Belgian traditions.  The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY.  Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition).  Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery.   In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast.  Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US.  In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink this if You Like

Blue Moon, Witbeirs, Wheat Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Soft and seductive beers, Traditional recipes 

# Drink While You Are

Touring the baseball hall of fame, Pruning citrus trees

# Pair With

Steamed Mussels, Chicken Piccata, Veal Parmesan

beers.description:
# Beer Description

Abita Wrought Iron IPA embodies the resilient, indestructible nature of New Orleans. This India pale ale is forged with the intensity of Apollo, Equinox and Mosaic Hops. Brewed with pale ale malt for a golden color as bright as iron from a fiery forge.

# The Boys'

Take: A bolder style beer then you would typically expect from the folks at Abita. Wrought Iron is an IPA with enough strong hop bitterness to live up to its name. A really excellent IPA from the folks at Abita.

# About the Brewer

Abita was founded in 1986, and is in many ways the quintessential Southern beer. Brewed in Abita Springs, LA (40 minutes north of New Orleans), Abita makes a wide range of brews, some of which are perfect for pairing with seersucker and sticky nights- and that's something we need here in the South. Another added benefit is the pure, deep water from Abita Springs- this is the last little bit that kicks Abita beer "up a notch!" Most Abita beers are light drinking and perfect for summer nights, and are made with all-natural, high-quality ingredients.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, IPAs, Double IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

New Orleans, front porches and ceiling fans, grits

# Drinking While you Are

Wrassling a gator, on a boat, done with some yardwork

# Pair with

Gumbo, Jambalaya, Low Country Boil, Crawfish Etouffee
